The '''social determinants of health''' ('''SDOH''') are the economic and social conditions and their distribution among the population that influence individual and group differences in [[health|health status]]. They are [[health promotion|health promoting]] factors found in one's living and working conditions (such as the distribution of income, wealth, influence, and power), rather than individual [[risk factor]]s (such as behavioural risk factors or genetics) that influence the risk for a [[disease]], or vulnerability to disease or [[injury]]. According to some viewpoints, the distributions of social determinants are shaped by public policies that reflect the influence of prevailing political ideologies of those governing a jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.thecanadianfacts.org/The_Canadian_Facts.pdf |title=Social Determinants of Health: The Canadian Facts |first1=Juha |last1=Mikkonen |first2=Dennis |last2=Raphael |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-9683484-1-3 }}{{pn|date=May 2015}}{{Self-published source|date=March 2012}}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] says, "This unequal distribution of health-damaging experiences is not in any sense a 'natural' phenomenon but is the result of a toxic combination of poor social policies, unfair economic arrangements [where the already well-off and healthy become even richer and the poor who are already more likely to be ill become even poorer], and bad politics."<ref name="WHO CSDH"/>
== Commonly accepted determinants ==
There is no single definition of the social determinants of health, but there are commonalities, and many governmental and non-governmental organizations recognize that there are social factors which impact the health of individuals.
In 2003, the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) Europe suggested that the social determinants of health included:<ref name="WHO Europe">{{cite book |url=http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/98438/e81384.pdf |title=The Social Determinants of Health: The Solid Facts |edition=2nd |format=PDF |year=2003 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] Europe |editor1-first=Richard |editor1-last=Wilkinson |editor2-first=Michael |editor2-last=Marmot |isbn=978-92-890-1371-0}}{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> * [[social class|Social gradients]] ([[life expectancy]] is shorter and disease is more common further down the social ladder) * [[stress (psychological)|Stress]] (including stress in the workplace) * [[Early childhood development]] * [[Social exclusion]] * [[Unemployment]] * [[Social support]] networks * [[Addiction]] * Availability of [[Healthy diet|healthy food]] * Availability of healthy transportation / [[active travel]] * Religion, caste, all the social diversities
In Canada, these social determinants of health have gained wide usage.<ref name=pmid20888059/> #[[Income]] and [[income distribution]] #[[Education]] #[[Unemployment]] and [[job security]] #[[Employment]] and [[working conditions]] #[[Early childhood development]] #[[Food insecurity]] #[[Housing]] #[[Social exclusion]] #[[Social safety net]]work #[[Health care|Health services]] #[[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Aboriginal]] status #[[Gender]] #[[Race (human classification)|Race]] #[[Disability]]
These SDOH are clearly related to health outcomes, are closely tied to public policy, and are clearly understandable by the public. They tend to cluster together – for example, those living in poverty also experience numerous other adverse social determinants. The quality and equitable distribution of these social determinants in Canada and the USA are clearly well below the standards seen in other developed nations.<ref name=pmid20888059>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2010.08.022 |pmid=20888059 |title=Canada: A land of missed opportunity for addressing the social determinants of health |journal=Health Policy |volume=101 |issue=1 |pages=44–58 |year=2011 |last1=Bryant |first1=Toba |last2=Raphael |first2=Dennis |last3=Schrecker |first3=Ted |last4=Labonte |first4=Ronald }}</ref>
The WHO later developed a Commission on Social Determinants of Health, which in 2008 published a report entitled "Closing the Gap in a Generation".<ref name="WHO CSDH">{{cite book |url=http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2008/9789241563703_eng.pdf |title=Closing the Gap in a Generation: Health Equity Through Action on the Social Determinants of Health |format=PDF |year=2008 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |author=Commission on Social Determinants of Health |accessdate=2013-03-27 |isbn=978-92-4-156370-3}}{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> This report identified two broad areas of social determinants of health that needed to be addressed. The first area was daily [[living conditions]], which included healthy [[physical environment]]s, fair employment and decent work, [[social protection]] across the lifespan, and access to health care. The second major area was distribution of power, money, and resources, including [[health equity|equity]] in health programs, public financing of action on the social determinants, [[economic inequality|economic inequalities]], [[resource depletion]], healthy working conditions, [[gender equality|gender equity]], [[political empowerment]], and a balance of power and prosperity of nations.<ref name="WHO CSDH"/>
The 2011 World Conference on Social Determinants of Health brought together delegations from 125 member states and resulted in the Rio Political Declaration on Social Determinants of Health. This declaration involved an affirmation that health inequities are unacceptable, and noted that these inequities arise from the societal conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age, including early childhood development, education, economic status, employment and decent work, housing environment, and effective prevention and treatment of health problems.<ref name="Rio Declaration">{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/sdhconference/declaration/Rio_political_declaration.pdf |title=Rio Political Declaration on Social Determinants of Health |format=PDF |year=2011 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |author=World Conference on Social Determinants of Health |accessdate=2013-03-27}}</ref>
The United States Centers for Disease Control defines social determinants of health as "life-enhancing resources, such as food supply, housing, economic and social relationships, transportation, education, and health care, whose distribution across populations effectively determines length and quality of life".<ref name="USCDC">{{cite book |first1=Laura K. |last1=Brennan Ramirez |first2=Elizabeth A. |last2=Baker |first3=Marilyn |last3=Metzler |url=http://www.cdc.gov/nccdphp/dch/programs/healthycommunitiesprogram/tools/pdf/SDOH-workbook.pdf |title=Promoting Health Equity: A Resource to Help Communities Address Social Determinants of Health |format=PDF |year=2008 |publisher=[[United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |accessdate=May 3, 2015 |page=6}}</ref> These include access to care and resources such as food, insurance coverage, income, housing, and transportation.<ref name="USCDC"/> Social determinants of health influence [[health promotion|health-promoting]] behaviours, and [[health equity]] among the population is not possible without equitable distribution of social determinants among groups.<ref name="USCDC"/>
Woolf states, "The degree to which social conditions affect health is illustrated by the association between education and mortality rates".<ref name="Woolf, S. H 2009">{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jama.2009.320 |pmid=19293418 |title=Social Policy as Health Policy |journal=JAMA |volume=301 |issue=11 |pages=1166–9 |year=2009 |last1=Woolf |first1=Steven H. }}</ref> Reports in 2005 revealed the [[mortality rate]] was 206.3 per 100,000 for adults aged 25 to 64 years with little education beyond high school, but was twice as great (477.6 per 100,000) for those with only a high school education and 3 times as great (650.4 per 100,000) for those less educated. Based on the data collected, the social conditions such as education, income, and race were very much dependent on one another, but these social conditions also apply independent health influences.<ref name="Woolf, S. H 2009"/>
Marmot and Bell found that in wealthy countries, income and mortality are correlated as a marker of relative position within society, and this relative position is related to social conditions that are important for health including good [[early childhood development]], access to good quality education, rewarding work with some degree of autonomy, decent housing, and a clean and safe living environment. The social condition of [[autonomy]], control, and empowerment turns are important influences on health and disease, and individuals who lack social participation and control over their lives are at a greater risk for heart disease and mental illness.<ref name="MarmotMichael">{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jama.2009.363 |pmid=19293419 |title=Action on Health Disparities in the United States |journal=JAMA |volume=301 |issue=11 |pages=1169–71 |year=2009 |last1=Marmot |first1=Michael G. |last2=Bell |first2=Ruth }}</ref>
== International health inequalities ==
Even in the wealthiest countries, there are economic inequalities in health between the rich and the poor.<ref name="WHO Europe"/> Canadian authors Labonte and Schrecker from the University of Ottawa note that globalization is a key context for the study of the social determinants of health, and as Bushra (2011) the impacts of globalization are asymmetric.<ref name="Labonte">{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1744-8603-3-6 |pmid=17578569 |pmc=1919362 |title=Globalization and social determinants of health: The role of the global marketplace (part 2 of 3) |journal=Globalization and Health |volume=3 |pages=6 |year=2007 |last1=Labonté |first1=Ronald |last2=Schrecker |first2=Ted }}</ref> As a result, there is an uneven distribution of wealth and influence both within and across national borders, leading to negative impacts on the social determinants of health. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development found significant differences among developed nations in [[ICU scoring systems|health status indicators]] such as life expectancy, [[infant mortality]], [[incidence (epidemiology)|incidence]] of disease, and death from injuries.<ref>Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. (2007). Health at a Glance 2007, OECD Indicators. Paris: Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref>
These inequalities may exist in the context of the [[health care system]], or in broader social approaches. According to the WHO's Commission on Social Determinants of Health, access to health care is essential for equitable health, and it argued that health care should be a common good rather than a market [[commodity]].<ref name="WHO CSDH"/> However, there is substantial variation in health care systems and coverage from country to country. The Commission also calls for government action on such things as access to clean water and safe, equitable working conditions, and it notes that dangerous working conditions exist even in some wealthy countries.<ref name=" WHO CSDH"/> In the Rio Political Declaration on Social Determinants of Health, several key areas of action were identified to address inequalities, including promotion of participatory [[public policy|policy]]-making processes, strengthening [[global governance]] and [[collaboration]], and encouraged developed countries to reach a target of 0.7% of [[gross national product]] (GNP) for official [[development assistance]].<ref name="Rio Declaration"/>
== Theoretical approaches ==
The UK ''Black'' and ''The Health Divide'' reports considered two primary mechanisms for understanding the process by which the social determinants influence health: cultural/ behavioural and [[materialist]]/structuralist.<ref>Townsend, P., Davidson, N., & Whitehead, M. (Eds.). (1992). Inequalities in Health: the Black Report and the Health Divide. New York: Penguin.{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> The cultural/behavioural explanation was that individuals' behavioural choices (e.g., tobacco and alcohol use, diet, physical activity, etc.) were responsible for their developing and dying from a variety of diseases. However, both the Black and Health divide reports found that behavioural choices are heavily structured by one's material conditions of life, and these behavioural [[risk factors]] account for a relatively small proportion of variation in the incidence and death from various diseases.
The materialist/structuralist explanation emphasizes the material conditions under which people live. These conditions include availability of resources to access the [[amenities]] of life, [[working conditions]], and quality of available food and housing among others. Within this view, three frameworks have been developed to explain how social determinants influence health.<ref>Bartley, M. (2003). Understanding Health Inequalities. Oxford UK: Polity Press.{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> These frameworks are: (a) materialist; (b) neo-materialist; and (c) [[psychosocial]] comparison. The materialist explanation is about how living conditions – and the social determinants of health that constitute these living conditions – shape health. The neo-materialist explanation extends the materialist analysis by asking how these living conditions come about. The psychosocial comparison explanation considers whether people compare themselves to others and how these comparisons affect health and wellbeing.
The wealth of nations is a strong indicator of population health. But within nations, [[socio-economic]] position is a powerful predictor of health as it is an indicator of material advantage or disadvantage over the lifespan.<ref name="Graham">Graham, H. (2007). Unequal Lives: Health and Socioeconomic Inequalities. New York: Open University Press.{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> Material conditions of life determine health by influencing the quality of individual development, family life and interaction, and community environments. Material conditions of life lead to differing likelihood of physical ([[infections]], [[malnutrition]], [[chronic disease]], and [[injuries]]), developmental (delayed or impaired [[cognitive development|cognitive]], [[personality development|personality]], and [[social development]]), educational ([[learning disabilities]], poor learning, early school leaving), and social ([[socialization]], preparation for work, and family life) problems.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shaw |first1=M. |last2=Dorling |first2=D. |last3=Gordon |first3=D. |last4=Smith |first4=G. D. |year=1999 |title=The Widening Gap: Health Inequalities and Policy in Britain |location=Bristol, UK |publisher=The Policy Press}}{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> Overall [[The Wealth of Nations|wealth of nations]] is a strong indicator of population health. But within nations, socio-economic position is a powerful predictor of health as it is an indicator of material advantage or disadvantage over the lifespan.<ref name="Graham" /> Material conditions of life also lead to differences in psychosocial stress<ref name="MarmotWilkinson2005pp6-30">{{cite book |doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198565895.003.02 |chapter=Social organization, stress, and health |title=Social Determinants of Health |pages=6–30 |year=2005 |last1=Marmot |first1=Michael |last2=Wilkinson |first2=Richard G. |isbn=978-0-19-856589-5 |editor1-first=Michael |editor1-last=Marmot |editor2-first=Richard |editor2-last=Wilkinson }}</ref> The fight-or-flight reaction – chronically elicited in response to threats such as income, housing, and food insecurity, among others – weakens the [[immune system]], leads to increased [[insulin resistance]], greater incidence of lipid and clotting disorders, and other biomedical insults that are precursors to adult disease.
Adoption of health-threatening behaviours is also influenced by material deprivation and stress.<ref name="MarmotWilkinson2005pp224-37">{{cite book |doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198565895.003.11 |chapter=Social patterning of individual health behaviours: The case of cigarette smoking |title=Social Determinants of Health |pages=224–37 |year=2005 |last1=Marmot |first1=Michael |last2=Wilkinson |first2=Richard G. |isbn=978-0-19-856589-5 |editor1-first=Michael |editor1-last=Marmot |editor2-first=Richard |editor2-last=Wilkinson }}</ref> Environments influence whether individuals take up tobacco, use alcohol, experience poor diets, and have low levels of physical activity. Tobacco and excessive alcohol use, and carbohydrate-dense diets are also means of coping with difficult circumstances.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wilkinson |first=R. G. |year=1996 |title=Unhealthy Societies: The Afflictions of Inequality |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0-415-09234-0}}{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref><ref name="MarmotWilkinson2005pp224-37"/> The materialist approach offers insight into the sources of health inequalities among individuals and nations and the role played by the social determinants of health.
The neo-materialist approach is concerned with how nations, regions, and cities differ on how economic and other resources are distributed among the population.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.320.7243.1200 |pmid=10784551 |pmc=1127589 |title=Income inequality and mortality: Importance to health of individual income, psychosocial environment, or material conditions |journal=BMJ |volume=320 |issue=7243 |pages=1200–4 |year=2000 |last1=Lynch |first1=J. W |last2=Smith |first2=G. D. |last3=Kaplan |first3=G. A. |last4=House |first4=J. S. }}</ref> This distribution of resources can vary widely from country to country. The neo-materialist view therefore, directs attention to both the effects of living conditions – the social determinants of health – on individuals' health and the societal factors that determine the quality of the distribution of these social determinants of health. How a society decides to distribute resources among citizens is especially important.
The social comparison approach holds that the social determinants of health play their role through citizens' interpretations of their standings in the [[social hierarchy]].<ref name=KawachiKennedy2002>{{cite book |last1=Kawachi |first1=I. |last2=Kennedy |first2=B. |year=2002 |title=The Health of Nations: Why Inequality Is Harmful to Your Health |location=New York |publisher=New Press}}{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> There are two mechanisms by which this occurs. At the individual level, the perception and experience of one's status in unequal societies lead to stress and poor health. Feelings of shame, worthlessness, and envy can lead to harmful effects upon neuro-endocrine, autonomic and metabolic, and immune systems.<ref name="MarmotWilkinson2005pp6-30"/> Comparisons to those of a higher social class can also lead to attempts to alleviate such feelings by overspending, taking on additional employment that threaten health, and adopting health-threatening coping behaviours such as overeating and using alcohol and tobacco.<ref name=KawachiKennedy2002/> At the communal level, widening and strengthening of hierarchy weakens [[social cohesion]], which is a determinant of health.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.314.7086.1037 |pmid=9112854 |pmc=2126438 |title=Socioeconomic determinants of health : Health and social cohesion: Why care about income inequality? |journal=BMJ |volume=314 |issue=7086 |pages=1037–40 |year=1997 |last1=Kawachi |first1=I. |last2=Kennedy |first2=B. P }}</ref> The social comparison approach directs attention to the psychosocial effects of public policies that weaken the social determinants of health. However, these effects may be secondary to how societies distribute material resources and provide security to its citizens, which are described in the materialist and neo-materialist approaches.{{fact|date=May 2015}}
== Life-course perspective ==
Life-course approaches emphasize the accumulated effects of experience across the life span in understanding the maintenance of health and the onset of disease. The economic and social conditions – the social determinants of health – under which individuals live their lives have a cumulative effect upon the probability of developing any number of diseases, including heart disease and stroke <ref name=Kumar2008>{{cite journal |last1=Kumar |first1=Rajiv |first2=Naveen K. |last2=Goel |title=Current Status Of Cardiovascular Risk Due To Stress |journal=Internet Journal of Health |volume=7 |issue=1 |year=2008 |pages=19 |url=https://ispub.com/IJH/7/1/10830 |doi=10.5580/1e7c}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Blane |first=D. |year=2006 |chapter=The life course, the social gradient and health |editor1-first=M. G. |editor1-last=Marmot |editor2-first=R. G. |editor2-last=Wilkinson |title=Social Determinants of Health |edition=2nd |pages=54–77 |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> Studies into the childhood and adulthood antecedents of adult-onset diabetes show that adverse economic and social conditions across the life span predispose individuals to this disorder.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.325.7368.805 |pmid=12376440 |pmc=128946 |title=Socioeconomic position in childhood and adulthood and insulin resistance: Cross sectional survey using data from British women's heart and health study |journal=BMJ |volume=325 |issue=7368 |pages=805 |year=2002 |last1=Lawlor |first1=D. A |last2=Ebrahim |first2=S |last3=Davey Smith |first3=G |author4=British women's heart health study }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1108/13660750310486730 |title=The social determinants of the incidence and management of type 2 diabetes mellitus: Are we prepared to rethink our questions and redirect our research activities? |journal=Leadership in Health Services |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=10–20 |year=2003 |last1=Raphael |first1=Dennis |last2=Anstice |first2=Susan |last3=Raine |first3=Kim |last4=McGannon |first4=Kerry R. |last5=Kamil Rizvi |first5=Syed |last6=Yu |first6=Vanessa }}</ref>
Hertzman outlines three [[health effect]]s that have relevance for a life-course perspective.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hertzman |first=Clyde |title=The case for an early childhood development strategy |journal=Isuma |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=11–8 |year=2000 |url=http://www.peelearlyyears.com/pdf/The%20Case%20for%20an%20Early%20Childhood%20Development%20Strategy,%20Canada.pdf }}</ref> Latent effects are biological or developmental early life experiences that influence health later in life. [[Birth weight|Low birth weight]], for instance, is a reliable predictor of incidence of cardiovascular disease and adult-onset diabetes in later life. Experience of nutritional deprivation during childhood has lasting health effects.
Pathway effects are experiences that set individuals onto trajectories that influence health, well-being, and competence over the life course. As one example, children who enter school with delayed vocabulary are set upon a path that leads to lower educational expectations, poor employment prospects, and greater likelihood of illness and disease across the lifespan. Deprivation associated with poor-quality neighbourhoods, schools, and housing sets children off on paths that are not conducive to health and well-being.{{fact|date=May 2015}}
Cumulative effects are the accumulation of advantage or disadvantage over time that manifests itself in poor health. These involve the combination of latent and pathways effects. Adopting a life-course perspective directs attention to how social determinants of health operate at every level of development – early childhood, childhood, adolescence, and adulthood – to both immediately influence health and provide the basis for health or illness later in life.{{fact|date=May 2015}}
==Chronic stress and health==
[[Stress (psychological)|Stress]] is hypothesised to be a major influence in the social determinants of health. There is a relationship between experience of chronic stress and negative health outcomes.<ref name=Gouin>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/1559827610395467 |title=Chronic Stress, Immune Dysregulation, and Health |journal=American Journal of Lifestyle Medicine |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=476–85 |year=2011 |last1=Gouin |first1=J.-P. }}</ref> There are two ways that this relationship is explained, through both direct and indirect effects of chronic stress on health outcomes.
One possible reason for the relationship between chronic stress and health outcomes is the effect that stress has on the physiology of a person. This is referred to as a direct relationship between chronic stress and health. The long term stress hormone, [[cortisol]], is believed to be the key driver in this relationship.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0033-2909.133.1.25 |pmid=17201569 |title=If it goes up, must it come down? Chronic stress and the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenocortical axis in humans |journal=Psychological Bulletin |volume=133 |issue=1 |pages=25–45 |year=2007 |last1=Miller |first1=Gregory E. |last2=Chen |first2=Edith |last3=Zhou |first3=Eric S. }}</ref> Chronic stress has been found to be significantly associated with chronic low grade inflammation, slower wound healing, increased susceptibility to infections, and poorer responses to vaccines.<ref name=Gouin></ref> For example, a study of otherwise healthy adult males found that those with high levels of perceived stress in their lives had significantly longer wound healing times, and that elevated cortisol levels, rather than health behaviour responses, appeared to be the main reason for this relationship.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0306-4530(03)00144-6 |pmid=15110929 |title=Perceived stress and cortisol levels predict speed of wound healing in healthy male adults |journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology |volume=29 |issue=6 |pages=798–809 |year=2004 |last1=Ebrecht |first1=Marcel |last2=Hextall |first2=Justine |last3=Kirtley |first3=Lauren-Grace |last4=Taylor |first4=Alice |last5=Dyson |first5=Mary |last6=Weinman |first6=John }}</ref> [[Meta-analysis]] of healing studies has found that there is a robust relationship between elevated stress levels and slower healing for many different acute and chronic conditions<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jpsychores.2009.04.002 |pmid=19686881 |title=Psychological stress and wound healing in humans: A systematic review and meta-analysis |journal=Journal of Psychosomatic Research |volume=67 |issue=3 |pages=253–71 |year=2009 |last1=Walburn |first1=Jessica |last2=Vedhara |first2=Kavita |last3=Hankins |first3=Matthew |last4=Rixon |first4=Lorna |last5=Weinman |first5=John }}</ref> However, it is also important to note that certain factors, such as coping styles and social support, can mitigate the relationship between chronic stress and health outcomes.<ref name=Cwikel>{{cite journal |last1=Cwikel |first1=Julie |last2=Segal-Engelchin |first2=Dorit |last3=Mendlinger |first3=Sheryl |title=Mothers' coping styles during times of chronic security stress: effect on health status | doi=10.1080/07399330903141245 |pmid=20390642 |journal= [[Health Care for Women International]] |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=131–52 |year=2010 | url = http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/07399330903141245 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first1=Sheldon |last1=Cohen |first2=Garth |last2=McKay |chapter=Social Support, Stress and the Buffering Hypothesis: A Theoretical Analysis |editor1-first=A. |editor1-last=Baum |editor2-first=S.E. |editor2-last=Taylor |editor3-first=J.E. |editor3-last=Singer |year=1984 |title=Handbook of Psychology and Health |pages=253–67 |chapterurl=http://www.psy.cmu.edu/~scohen/buffer84.pdf}}</ref>
Stress can also be seen to have an indirect effect on health status. One way this happens is due to the strain on the psychological resources of the stressed individual. Chronic stress is common in those of a low socio-economic status, who are having to balance worries about financial security, how they will feed their families, housing status, and many other concerns.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/phe/phs022 |title=Behavior Change or Empowerment: On the Ethics of Health-Promotion Strategies |journal=Public Health Ethics |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=140–53 |year=2012 |last1=Tengland |first1=P.-A. }}</ref> Therefore, individuals with these kinds of worries may lack the emotional resources to adopt positive health behaviours. Chronically stressed individuals may therefore be less likely to be able to prioritise their health.
In addition to this, the way that an individual responds to stress can influence their health status. Often, individuals responding to chronic stress will develop coping behaviours, some of which have a positive influences on health and others which have a negative influence. People who cope with stress through positive behaviours such as exercise or social connections may not be as affected by the relationship between stress and health, whereas those with a coping style more prone to over consumption (i.e. [[emotional eating]], drinking, smoking or drug use) are more likely to be see negative health effects of stress.<ref name=Cwikel></ref> For example, a laboratory study has shown that, while stress did not alter calorie intake or food type eaten when averaged across the sample as a whole, when looking at a subset of the sample who were classed as emotional eaters, high stress levels were associated with eating more high fat and sweet food and a more calorie dense meal overall.<ref name=Oliver>{{cite journal |pmid=11139006 |url=http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0033-3174&volume=62&issue=6&spage=853 |year=2000 |author1=Oliver |first1=G |title=Stress and food choice: A laboratory study |journal=[[Psychosomatic Medicine (journal)|Psychosomatic Medicine]] |volume=62 |issue=6 |pages=853–65 |last2=Wardle |first2=J |last3=Gibson |first3=E. L. |doi=10.1097/00006842-200011000-00016}}</ref> Therefore, the authors conclude that stress may compromise the health of certain susceptible individuals (I.e those with an emotional eating coping style).<ref name=Oliver></ref>
The detrimental effects of stress on health outcomes are hypothesised to partly explain why countries that have high levels of income inequality have poorer health outcomes compared to more equal countries.<ref name=WP>Wilkinson, R. & Pickett, K. (2009) The spirit level : why more equal societies almost always do better. London: Allen Lane.{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref> Wilkinson and Picket hypothesise in their book [[The Spirit Level: Why More Equal Societies Almost Always Do Better|The Spirit Level]] that the stressors associated with low social status are amplified in societies where others are clearly far better off.<ref name=WP/>
==Improving health conditions worldwide==
Reducing the health gap in a generation requires that governments build systems that allow a healthy standard of living where no one should fall below due to circumstances beyond his or her control. Social protection schemes can be instrumental in realizing developmental goals rather than being dependent on achieving those goals. They can be effective ways to reduce [[poverty]] and local economies can benefit.<ref name="WHO CSDH" />
Policies to reduce [[child poverty]] are particularly important, as elevated stress hormones in children interfere with the development of brain circuitry and connections, causing long term chemical damage.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.0811910106 |jstor=40482133 |pmid=19332779 |pmc=2662958 |title=Childhood poverty, chronic stress, and adult working memory |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=106 |issue=16 |pages=6545–9 |year=2009 |last1=Evans |first1=G. W. |last2=Schamberg |first2=M. A. |bibcode=2009PNAS..106.6545E }}</ref> Studies showed that the [[immune system]] of participants were stronger if their parents had the security of home ownership while the participants were growing up.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} In most wealthy countries, the relative child poverty rate is 10 percent or less; in the United States, it is 21.9 percent.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} The lowest poverty rates are more common in smaller well-developed and high-spending welfare states like Sweden and Finland, with about 5 or 6 percent.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} Middle-level rates are found in major European countries where unemployment compensation is more generous and social policies provide more generous support to single mothers and working women (through paid family leave, for example), and where social assistance minimums are high. For instance, the Netherlands, Austria, Belgium and Germany have poverty rates that are in the 7 to 8 percent range.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1257/089533006776526094 |jstor=30033634 |title=Poor People in Rich Nations: The United States in Comparative Perspective |journal=Journal of Economic Perspectives |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=69–90 |year=2006 |last1=Smeeding |first1=Timothy }}</ref>
The Commission on Social Determinants of Health (CSDH) in 2005 made recommendations for action to promote health equity based on 3 principles of action: "improve the circumstances in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age; tackle the inequitable distribution of power, money, and resources, the structural drivers of conditions of daily life, globally, nationally, and locally; and measure the problem, evaluate action, and expand the knowledge base."<ref name="MarmotMichael" /> These recommendations would involve providing resources such as quality education, decent housing, access to affordable health care, access to healthy food, and safe places to exercise for everyone despite gaps in affluence. Expansion of knowledge of the social determinants of health, including among healthcare workers, can improve the quality and standard of care for people who are marginalized, poor or living in developing nations by preventing early death and disability while working to improve quality of life.<ref name="Farmer">{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0030449 |pmid=17076568 |pmc=1621099 |title=Structural Violence and Clinical Medicine |journal=PLoS Medicine |volume=3 |issue=10 |pages=e449 |year=2006 |last1=Farmer |first1=Paul E. |last2=Nizeye |first2=Bruce |last3=Stulac |first3=Sara |last4=Keshavjee |first4=Salmaan }}</ref>
== Public policy ==
The Rio Political Declaration on Social Determinants of Health embraces a transparent, participatory model of policy development that, among other things, addresses the social determinants of health leading to persistent health inequalities for indigenous peoples.<ref name="Rio Declaration"/>
The United States Department of Health and Human Services includes social determinants in its model of population health, and one of its missions is to strengthen policies which are backed by the best available evidence and knowledge in the field <ref>{{cite web |url=http://healthypeople.gov/2020/Consortium/HP2020Framework.pdf |title=Healthy People 2020 Framework |format=PDF |year=2010 |publisher=United States Department of Health and Human Services |accessdate=2013-03-27}}</ref> Social determinants of health do not exist in a vacuum. Their quality and availability to the population are usually a result of public policy decisions made by governing authorities. For example, early life is shaped by availability of sufficient material resources that assure adequate educational opportunities, food and housing among others. Much of this has to do with the employment security and the quality of working conditions and wages. The availability of quality, regulated childcare is an especially important policy option in support of early life.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Gøsta |last1=Esping-Andersen |chapter=A Child-Centred Social Investment Strategy |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=OaxGR8yrm10C&pg=PA26 |pages=26–67 |editor1-first==Gøsta |editor1-last=Esping-Andersen |year=2002 |title=Why We Need a New Welfare State |isbn=978-0-19-925642-6}}</ref> These are not issues that usually come under individual control. A policy-oriented approach places such findings within a broader policy context. In this context, [[Health in All Policies]] has seen as a response to incorporate health and health equity into all public policies as means to foster synergy between sectors and ultimately promote health.
Yet it is not uncommon to see governmental and other authorities individualize these issues. Governments may view early life as being primarily about parental behaviours towards their children. They then focus upon promoting better parenting, assist in having parents read to their children, or urge schools to foster exercise among children rather than raising the amount of financial or housing resources available to families. Indeed, for every social determinant of health, an individualized manifestation of each is available. There is little evidence to suggest the efficacy of such approaches in improving the health status of those most vulnerable to illness in the absence of efforts to modify their adverse living conditions.<ref>{{cite book |last=Raphael |first=D. |year=2001 |title=Inequality is Bad for our Hearts: Why Low Income and Social Exclusion are Major Causes of Heart Disease in Canada |isbn=0-9689444-0-X}}{{pn|date=May 2015}}</ref>
One of the recommendations by the CSDH is expanding knowledge – particularly to health care workers.<ref name="Farmer" />
==Power== A recent article outlines the role that "raw power" plays in shaping the distribution of the social determinants of health through public policy action.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/heapro/dau044 |pmid=24870808 |title=Beyond policy analysis: The raw politics behind opposition to healthy public policy |journal=Health Promotion International |year=2014 |last1=Raphael |first1=D. |volume=30 |pages=380–96}}</ref> Here the business sector is seen as shaping public policy to increase profits as the expense of the population's health. This is a political economy approach that is typically ignored in discussions of the social determinants of health.
